info.meta: Configure, manage and monitor network connections with NetworkManager

listitem.para: NetworkManager is a dynamic network control and configuration tool that enables you to keep network devices up and running.
This article provides a complete overview of NetworkManager and how to configure, manage, monitor and edit network connections using NetworkManager.
It takes 15 minutes to install and configure NetworkManager. You need up to an hour to fully understand the NetworkManager concept and functionalities.
Basic understanding of managing network connections.
Root access to install and manage NetworkManager
A package manager to install NetworkManager

abstract.para: NetworkManager is a tool that enables managing network connections and devices. NetworkManager allows you to create, configure and manage network connections and devices.

section.para: On SLE HA, NetworkManager has been designed to be fully automatic by default. It is enabled by default and is shipped with all necessary service unit files for managing primary network connection and other network interfaces. NetworkManager supports state-of-the-art encryption types and standards for network connections, including connections to 802.1X protected networks. 802.1X is the IEEE Standard for Local and Metropolitan Area Networks—Port-Based Network Access Control.

You can switch between wired or wireless networks seamlessly, as NetworkManager automatically connects to known wireless networks and manages several network connections in parallel. You can also manually switch between available networks.
NetworkManager typically consists of the following parts:

listitem.para: NetworkManager daemon—you can interact with the daemon using standard systemd commands
the nmcli command-line interface
the ncurses interface nmtui
NetworkManager libraries
configuration files.

abstract.para: On SUSE Linux Enterprise High Availability, NetworkManager is installed and enabled by default and thus runs out of the box. Usually, you do not have to reinstall it or change the configuration, but if such an action is needed, these sections provide guidance.
You can install NetworkManager using zypper. Once you install, you can enable NetworkManager to start automatically at boot time.

abstract.para: The behavior of NetworkManager is defined in its central configuration file /etc/NetworkManager/NetworkManager.conf.

section.para: It is the primary location for configuring behavior and settings of NetworkManager, including logging, connection management, and network device handling.

The file consists of sections of key-value pairs. Each key-value pair must belong to a section. A section starts with a name enclosed in []. Lines beginning with a # are considered comments. A common configuration includes the [main] section with the plugins value, [logging], and [connectivity]:

abstract.para: You can create a network connection profile using the nmcli command.

section.para: NetworkManager stores all network configurations as a connection profile, which is a collection of data that describes how to create or connect to a network. These connection profiles are stored as files in the /etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/ directory by default. Each network connection profile (Wi-Fi, Ethernet, VPN) is represented by a separate file in this directory.

A connection is an instance of a particular connection profile that is active when a particular device uses the connection. The device may have more than one connection profile configured. The other connections can be used to fast switch from one connection to another. For example, if the active connection is not available, NetworkManager tries to connect the device to another configured connection.

section.title: Creating an Ethernet connection
section.para: Configure the Ethernet connection using the nmcli command and proceed as follows:

step.para: List available devices to get the exact device name:
step.screen: > nmcli device

step.para: View the list of connections to make sure the profile name you want to use is not already taken:
step.screen: nmcli connection show
step.para: The NetworkManager creates a profile for each Network Interface Controller (NIC). To connect the NIC to networks with different settings, you must create separate profiles for each network.
Create a new connection profile:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add con-name CONNECTION_NAME ifname DEVICE_NAME type ethernet

step.para: View the existing network settings of the new connection profile:
step.screen: > nmcli connection show CONNECTION_NAME

step.para: Configure the connection profile. The generic command syntax is the following:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify CONNECTION_NAME SETTING VALUE
step.para: For example, automatic IP addresses assignment (DHCP or SLAAC) is enabled by default, and you may want to configure a static IP address:

listitem.para: for IPv4
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify CONNECTION_NAME ipv4.method manual ipv4.addresses 192.0.2.1/24 ipv4.gateway 192.0.2.254 ipv4.dns 192.0.2.200 ipv4.dns-search example.com

listitem.para: for IPv6
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify INTERNAL-LAN ipv6.method manual ipv6.addresses 2001:db8:1::fffe/64 ipv6.gateway 2001:db8:1::fffe ipv6.dns 2001:db8:1::ffbb ipv6.dns-search example.com

step.para: Activate the profile:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection up CONNECTION_NAME

step.para: Verify the configurations:
Verify the IP settings of the NIC:
step.screen: > ip address show HOSTNAME

step.para: Verify the default IPv4 gateway:
step.screen: > ip route show default

step.para: Verify the default IPv6 gateway:
step.screen: > ip -6 route show default

step.para: View the DNS settings:
step.screen: > cat /etc/resolv.conf

section.title: Creating a Wi-Fi connection profile
section.para: You can connect to a Wi-Fi using the nmcli command. The NetworkManager creates a new connection profile when you connect to a Wi-Fi for the first time. You can configure the profile after connecting to the Wi-Fi.

step.para: Enable the Wi-Fi radio:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli radio wifi on

step.para: View the list of available devices:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli device

step.para: Connect to Wi-Fi:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli device wifi connect WI-FI_CONNECTION_NAME PASSWORD

step.para: View the existing network settings of the new connection profile:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection show CONNECTION_NAME

step.para: Configure the connection profile as needed, using the command:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify CONNECTION_NAME SETTING VALUE
step.para: For example, to configure a static IPv4:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify WI-FI_CONNECTION_NAME ipv4.method manual ipv4.addresses IP_ADDRESS/SUBNET_MASK
step.para: To configure a static IPv6 address
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify WI-FI_CONNECTION_NAME ipv6.method manual ipv6.addresses IP_ADDRESS/SUBNET_MASK

step.para: Restart the connection:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection up WI-FI_CONNECTION_NAME

step.para: Verify the connection using the command: .
The list of available active connections appears.

section.title: Creating a network bond
section.para: A network bond combines physical and virtual network interfaces and provides a logical interface. You can create network bonds on Ethernet devices, Virtual LANs, and so on.
You must have two or more physical or virtual networks installed on the server.

listitem.para: To use Ethernet devices for network bonding, you must install the physical or virtual Ethernet devices on the server.
When using network teams, bridges or VLAN devices as ports for a bond, you can create them either during the bond creation process or beforehand.

step.para: Create a bond interface:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add type bond con-name NWBOND ifname NWBOND bond.options "mode=active-backup"
step.para: A network bond, NETWORK_BOND that uses active-backup mode is created.
View the list of network interfaces:
step.screen:
> nmcli device status
DEVICE TYPE STATE CONNECTION wlan0 wifi connected Vision virbr0 bridge connected (externally) virbr0 p2p-dev-wlan0 wifi-p2p disconnected -- eth0 ethernet unavailable -- lo loopback unmanaged --
step.para: The list of available network interfaces appears. You can also add devices that are not configured to the bond. In the given list, p2p-dev-wlan0 is not configured, while virbr0 is configured and has a connection profile.
To configure p2p-dev-wlan0 as a port, create a connection profile:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add type wifi-p2p slave-type bond con-name bond0-port1 ifname p2p-dev-wlan0 master bond0
step.para: A new profile is created for p2p-dev-wlan0 and added to the bond0 connection. The name of the bond is bond0.
To assign virbr0 to a bond:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify virbr0 master bond0
step.para: The connection profile for virbr0 is added to the bond0 connection.
Activate the connection:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection up virbr0

step.para: Configure the IPv4 settings:

listitem.para: To use bond0 as a port for other devices:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bond0 ipv4.method disabled

listitem.para: To use DHCP, no configuration is required.
To configure a static IPv4 address, network mask, default gateway and DNS server to the bond0 connection:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bond0 ipv4.addresses '192.0.2.1/24' ipv4.gateway '192.0.2.254' ipv4.dns '192.0.2.253' ipv4.dns-search 'example.com' ipv4.method manual

step.para: Configure the IPv6 settings:

listitem.para: To use this bond device as a port of other devices:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bond0 ipv6.method disabled

listitem.para: To use stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC), no action is required.
To set a static IPv6 address, network mask, default gateway and DNS server to the bond0 connection:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bond0 ipv6.addresses '2001:db8:1::1/64' ipv6.gateway '2001:db8:1::fffe' ipv6.dns '2001:db8:1::fffd' ipv6.dns-search 'example.com' ipv6.method manual

step.para: Activate the connection:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection up bond0

step.para: View and verify the connections:
step.screen: > nmcli device
step.para: The list of connections appears.

section.title: Configuring a network team
section.para: Network teaming combines physical and virtual networks and provides a logical interface with higher efficiency. Configure network teams using nmcli.

listitem.para: Install the teamd and NetworkManager-team packages:
listitem.screen: > sudo zypper install teamd > sudo zypper install NetworkManager-team

listitem.para: Install two or more physical or virtual devices on the server:
To use Ethernet devices as ports of the team, the physical or virtual Ethernet devices must be installed on the server and connected to a switch.
To use bond, bridge or VLAN devices as ports of the team, create them in advance or when you create the team.

step.para: Create a team interface:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add type team con-name CONNECTION_NAME ifname TEAM_NAME team.runner RUNNER-TYPE
step.para: For example, to create a network team team0 with the activebackup runner, run:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add type team con-name team0 ifname team0 team.runner active.backup

step.para: View the list of network interfaces:
step.screen: > nmcli device status
DEVICE TYPE STATE CONNECTION wlan0 wifi connected Vision virbr0 bridge connected (externally) virbr0 p2p-dev-wlan0 wifi-p2p disconnected -- eth0 ethernet unavailable -- lo loopback unmanaged --
step.para: You can add the listed devices to the team. The following examples use p2p-dev-wlan0 and virbr0. Note that p2p-dev-wlan0 is not configured, while virbr0 has a connection profile.
Configure port interfaces to the team:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add type wifi-p2p slave-type team con-name team0-port1 ifname p2p-dev-wlan0 master team0
step.para: A new profile is created for p2p-dev-wlan0 and added to the team0 connection.
Assign the existing connection to the team:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bond0 master team0
step.para: The connection profile for bond0 is added to the team0 connection.
Activate the connection:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection up bond0

step.para: Configure the IPv4 settings:

listitem.para: To use the team device as a port of other devices:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify team0 ipv4.method disabled

listitem.para: To use DHCP, no configuration is required.
To configure a static IPv4 address, network mask, default gateway and DNS server to the bond0 connection, run the command:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify team0 ipv4.addresses '192.0.2.1/24' ipv4.gateway '192.0.2.254' ipv4.dns '192.0.2.253' ipv4.dns-search 'example.com' ipv4.method manual

step.para: Configure the IPv6 settings:

listitem.para: To use this team device as a port of other devices:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify team0 ipv6.method disabled

listitem.para: To use stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC), no action is required.
To set a static IPv6 address, network mask, default gateway and DNS server to the team0 connection:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify team0 ipv6.addresses '2001:db8:1::1/64' ipv6.gateway '2001:db8:1::fffe' ipv6.dns '2001:db8:1::fffd' ipv6.dns-search 'example.com' ipv6.method manual

step.para: Activate the connection:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection up team0

step.para: To view the status of the team:
step.screen: > sudo teamdctl team0 state

section.title: Configuring a network bridge
section.para: A network bridge is a device that facilitates communication between two or more network segments, creating a single network from multiple segments
To configure a network bridge, ensure the following:

listitem.para: Install two or more physical or virtual devices on the server.
To use Ethernet devices as ports for the bridge, ensure the server has physical or virtual Ethernet devices installed and connected to a switch.
When using team, bond or VLAN devices as ports for the bridge, you can create these devices either during bridge creation or beforehand.

step.para: Create a bridge interface:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add type bridge con-name CONNECTION_NAME ifname BRIDGE_NAME
step.para: For example, we created a bridge: bridge0 by running the command:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add type bridge con-name bridge0 ifname bridge0

step.para: View the list of network interfaces to verify that bridge0 is created:
step.screen:
> nmcli device status
DEVICE TYPE STATE CONNECTION wlan0 wifi connected Vision virbr0 bridge connected (externally) virbr0 p2p-dev-wlan0 wifi-p2p disconnected -- eth0 ethernet unavailable -- lo loopback unmanaged -- bridge0 bridge connecting (getting IP configuration) brdige0
step.para: The bridge is in the state getting IP configuration, because you have not assigned interfaces to it yet. Later you will assign the interfaces: p2p-dev-wlan0 (not configured) and virbr0 (configured with a connection profile).
Add interfaces to the bridge:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add type wifi-p2p slave-type bridge con-name bridge0-port1 ifname p2p-dev-wlan0 master bridge0
step.para: A new profile is created for p2p-dev-wlan0 and added to the bridge0 connection.
To assign an existing connection to the bridge:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bond0 master bridge0
step.para: The connection profile for bond0 is added to the bridge0 connection.
Restart the connection:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection up bond0

step.para: Configure the IPv4 settings:

listitem.para: To use the bridge device as a port of other devices:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bridge0 ipv4.method disabled

listitem.para: To use DHCP, no configuration is required.
To configure a static IPv4 address, network mask, default gateway and DNS server to the bridge0 connection:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bridge0 ipv4.addresses '192.0.2.1/24' ipv4.gateway '192.0.2.254' ipv4.dns '192.0.2.253' ipv4.dns-search 'example.com' ipv4.method manual

step.para: Configure the IPv6 settings:

listitem.para: To use this bridge device as a port of other devices:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bridge0 ipv6.method disabled

listitem.para: To use stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC), no action is required.
To set a static IPv6 address, network mask, default gateway and DNS server to the bridge0 connection:
listitem.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bridge0 ipv6.addresses '2001:db8:1::1/64' ipv6.gateway '2001:db8:1::fffe' ipv6.dns '2001:db8:1::fffd' ipv6.dns-search 'example.com' ipv6.method manual

step.para: Activate the connection:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection up bridge0

step.para: Verify the connection:
step.screen: > nmcli device
step.para: When you activate any port of the connection, NetworkManager also activates the bridge, but not the other ports of it.
Enable all ports automatically when the bridge is enabled:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify bridge0 connection.autoconnect-slaves 1

step.para: View the link status of Ethernet devices that are ports of a specific bridge.
step.screen: > sudo ip link show master bridge0

step.para: View the status of Ethernet devices that are ports of any bridge device.
step.screen: > sudo bridge link show

section.title: Configuring a VPN connection
section.para: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) connection is a secure, encrypted tunnel between your device and another network over the Internet.
You can configure a VPN connection using the nmcli command.

procedure.title: Installing and configuring a VPN connection

step.para: Install OpenVPN:
step.screen: > sudo zypper install networkmanager-openvpn

step.para: Create a VPN connection:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection add type vpn con-name MyOpenVPN ifname -- vpn-type openvpn

step.para: Configure the settings:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify MyOpenVPN vpn.data "remote=VPN-SERVER-ADDRESS,username=YOUR-USERNAME"
> sudo nmcli connection modify MyOpenVPN vpn.secrets "password=YOUR-PASSWORD"

step.para: Configure DNS settings:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify MyOpenVPN ipv4.dns "8.8.8.8 8.8.4.4"

step.para: Add routes:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection modify MyOpenVPN ipv4.routes "192.168.1.0/24 192.168.1.1"

step.para: Activate the VPN connections:
step.screen: > sudo nmcli connection up MyOpenVPN

step.para: Verify if the configured connection is active:
step.screen: > nmcli connection show --active

abstract.para: NetworkManager activities are logged by the journald system logging mechanism. The NetworkManager logs are saved in /var/log/syslog, and you can access the details using the journalctl command.

section.para: The type of logged NetworkManager activities differs according to the current logging level. Available levels are described below:

listitem.para: ERR—logs only error messages. For example, connection failures.
WARN—logs warnings and errors. For example, authentication issues.
INFO—logs informational messages. That is the default level for all logging domains.
DEBUG—logs detailed debugging information. For example, detailed DHCP negotiations
TRACE—logs very detailed, usually unimportant events. For example, packet-level details.

section.para: To check the current logging level, run:

The output shows that the logging level is INFO for all domains—that is the default setting. You can modify logging levels on particular domains and then the command outputs only the modified domains.
To change the logging level on all domains, run:

screen.command: general logging level LEVEL domains ALL

section.para: For example, to revert changes to the default setting:

screen.command: nmcli general logging level INFO domains ALL

section.para: To change a logging level on particular domains, for example, to set DEBUG on DNS and FIREWALL, run:

screen.command: nmcli general logging level DEBUG domains FIREWALL,DNS

section.title: The general subcommand
section.para: You can use this command to view NetworkManager status and permissions, and change the host name and logging level. The nmcli general recognizes the following commands:

listitem.para: displays the overall status of NetworkManager. Whenever you do not specify a command to the nmcli general command, status is used by default.
if you do not provide a new host name as an argument, the current host name is displayed. If you specify a new host name, the value is used to set a new host name.
For example, to set MyHostname, run:
shows your permission for NetworkManager operations like enabling or disabling networking, modifying connections, etc.
shows and changes NetworkManager logging levels and domains. Without any arguments, the command displays current logging levels and domains.

screen.command: nmcli general logging [level LEVEL domains DOMAIN]

listitem.para: LEVEL is any of the values: OFF, ERR, WARN, INFO, DEBUG, or TRACE.

DOMAIN is a list of values that can be as follows: PLATFORM, RFKILL, ETHER, WIFI, BT, MB, DHCP4, DHCP6, PPP, WIFI_SCAN, IP4, IP6, AUTOIP4, DNS, VPN, SHARING, SUPPLICANT, AGENTS, SETTINGS, SUSPEND, CORE, DEVICE, OLPC, WIMAX, INFINIBAND, FIREWALL, ADSL, BOND, VLAN, BRIDGE, DBUS_PROPS, TEAM, CONCHECK, DCB, DISPATCH, AUDIT, SYSTEMD, VPN_PLUGIN, PROXY.

section.title: The networking subcommand
section.para: The subcommand enables you to query the status of the network. Also, by using this command, you can enable or disable networking. The nmcli networking command takes the following commands:

listitem.para: enables or disables networking. The off command deactivates all interfaces managed by NetworkManager.
displays the network connectivity state. If check is used, NetworkManager performs a new check of the state. Otherwise, the last detected state is displayed.
Possible states are the following:
none - the host is not connected to any network.
portal - the host is behind a captive portal and cannot reach the full Internet.
limited - the host is connected to a network, but it has no access to the Internet.
full - the host is connected to a network and has full access to the Internet.
unknown - NetworkManager could not determine the network state.
